rComments: Prof Haas is really nice and knowledgeable about the material but this apparently her first time teaching this class in a while so it was not structured  well. There are 3 assignments and they all came during the last 3 weeks of the quarter which is a little ridiculous. (so its impossible to know how you're doing) if better structured would rec

Her lectures can sometimes tangent, and be hard to follow. And like any history class, there is a lot of reading (sometime a book per week). But beyond that, it's obvious that her passion for history shines through, and her incredible intellect as well.

Prof. Haas assigned about 8 books for this class (they were pricey) and we must read the books by the following week (as we would discuss them in section and lecture). Attendance is only mandatory for section (30% of grade). Participate in section! Lectures can get boring but they are helpful. Take notes in section and lecture! Only had 2 exams.

Women's History, Senior Seminar on writing history. I always looked forward to her lectures, and her revisionist approach to teaching history, for looking under the surface of the official and finding the personal. I took three classes with her between 99-00, and thought they were insigntful, intelligent and well-planned. Her classes always got me spinning off to somewhere in time, even after the lecture.

I took three classes from professor Haas while at Santa Cruz and she was my major advisor. In my experiences in her class were always good. She's an easy "A," clear, nice, and flexible. She loves her subject too, so if (God forbid) you are into history, she's a great teacher. Thumbs up.
A little flighty, lectures can get off topic. But she knows her stuff, and usually supplements the lectures with multimedia. Has a tendency to change her assignment instructions last minute.
